title: What does it mean to be a refugee? - Benedetta Berti and Evelien Borgman

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many people around the globe have been forced to leave their homes to escape war, violence, and persecution?
What is the term for people who have fled their homes but are still within their own countries?
What is the modern definition of a refugee, according to the UN's 1951 Convention relating to the status of refugees?

options.label: A
options.text: Someone who is outside their country of nationality and is unable to return to their home country due to well-founded fears of persecution.

options.label: B
options.text: Someone who is outside their country of nationality and is unable to return to their home country due to economic hardship.

options.label: C
options.text: Someone who is outside their country of nationality and is unable to return to their home country due to natural disasters.

options.label: D
options.text: Someone who is outside their country of nationality and is unable to return to their home country due to political unrest.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for people who leave their country for reasons not related to persecution, such as searching for better economic opportunities?
What happens when someone flees their country, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: They usually travel by airplane and have access to shelter, water, and food.

options.label: B
options.text: They usually travel by land or sea and may need to entrust their lives to smugglers to cross borders.

options.label: C
options.text: They usually travel by car and have access to medical care.

options.label: D
options.text: They usually stay in their home country and do not leave.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first legal step for a displaced person in a new country?
What is the principle that prevents a nation from sending an individual to a country where their life and freedom are threatened?
What is the term for the victims of inconsistent and discriminatory treatment?
What is the obligation of host countries towards people they have recognized as refugees?

options.label: A
options.text: To guarantee a minimum standard of treatment and non-discrimination.

options.label: B
options.text: To provide medical care and education.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it good for us to remember the stories of refugees currently displaced, searching for a new home?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it helps us to understand their struggles and challenges.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it reminds us of our own ancestors who were forced from their homes.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it gives us a sense of hope and resilience.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it reminds us of our own history and culture.

title: The evolution of the book - Julie Dreyfuss

multiple-choice.question: What is considered the earliest object that we think of as a book?

options.label: C
options.text: A stack of pages bound along one edge

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with the invention of the printing press?
What is the name of the concept that had been invented much earlier in Eastern culture, but was introduced by Gutenberg's press?

options.label: B
options.text: Oil-based ink made of lamp soot, turpentine, and walnut oil

options.label: C
options.text: A mixture of animal dyes and clay

options.label: D
options.text: A combination of metal and ink

What was the original material used for covers before the late 17th century?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the book easier to read

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent the book from closing in on itself

options.label: C
options.text: To make the book more aesthetically pleasing

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the weight of the book

What is the author suggesting is the essence of a book, according to the transcript?

title: Are You A Good Listener?

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the most important life skills that few of us know how to do?
Why do people come to social life "greedy to speak rather than listen"?

options.label: B
options.text: Because no one has taught them how to listen

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the things that the good listener is doing that makes it nice to spend time in their company?

options.label: D
options.text: They don't care about our feelings

multiple-choice.question: What is the "ambition to clarify the underlying issues" that the good listener brings to listening?

options.label: A
options.text: To help us remember what we said

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the things that the good listener doesn't do?

options.label: D
options.text: They don't care about our feelings

multiple-choice.question: Why do people often feel that being disagreed with is an expression of hostility?

options.label: C
options.text: Because a good listener makes it clear that they can really like you and at the same time think you're wrong

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the ways that the good listener signals sympathy without intruding on what we're trying to say?

options.label: A
options.text: By making occasional little positive sounds

options.label: D
options.text: By not caring about our feelings

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the keys to a good Society through life?
What is one of the things that troubles people around communicating their intentions and emotions clearly and honestly?

options.label: C
options.text: There isn't a whole lot of room for subjectivity

title: The microbial jungles all over the place (and you) - Scott Chimileski and Roberto Kolter

multiple-choice.question: What are microbes that gather by the millions to form vast communities known as?
What are natural biofilms like?

options.label: A
options.text: They are composed of a single type of microbe.

options.label: B
options.text: They are like miniature jungles filled with many kinds of microbes.

options.label: C
options.text: They are made up of only bacteria and archaea.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not found in nature.

multiple-choice.question: What do microbes use to propel themselves towards the surface of a rock?
What is the extracellular matrix that holds microbes together as they divide and reproduce?
Why do microbes build complex communities like biofilms?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they have access to a nutrient source and are shielded from external threats.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are able to communicate and exchange genetic information.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are able to compete with other microbes.

multiple-choice.question: What is division of labor in a biofilm?

options.label: A
options.text: The process by which individual cells differentiate into different subpopulations.

options.label: B
options.text: The process by which cells work together to accomplish a task.

options.label: C
options.text: The process by which cells compete with each other for resources.

options.label: D
options.text: The process by which cells produce extracellular matrix.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the extracellular matrix in a biofilm?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide a nutrient source for the microbes.

options.label: B
options.text: To protect the microbes from external threats.

options.label: D
options.text: To provide a physical structure for the microbes to attach to.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of biofilms to humans and other species?

options.label: A
options.text: They produce oxygen and help clean up environmental pollution.

options.label: B
options.text: They are used as a source of food and flavor.

options.label: C
options.text: They are used to treat wastewater.

multiple-choice.question: Where are biofilms commonly found?

options.label: A
options.text: In soil and on plant roots.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of competition between microbes in a biofilm?

options.label: A
options.text: The elimination of one species and the survival of another.

options.label: B
options.text: The formation of a cooperative relationship between species.

options.label: D
options.text: The differentiation of cells into different subpopulations.

title: Why is the US Constitution so hard to amend? - Peter Paccone

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the U.S. Constitution is difficult to change?

options.label: A
options.text: The founders of the United States were trying to create a unified country from thirteen different colonies.

options.label: B
options.text: The Constitution's creators wanted to make it hard to change.

options.label: C
options.text: The Constitution's creators wanted to create a unified country from thirteen different colonies and needed assurance that their agreements couldn't be easily undone.

options.label: D
options.text: The Constitution's creators wanted to make it easy to change.

multiple-choice.question: What is the minimum number of states required to ratify an amendment to the U.S. Constitution?
What is the first step to propose an amendment to the U.S. Constitution?

options.label: A
options.text: A two-thirds vote of approval in both houses of Congress

options.label: B
options.text: A request from two-thirds of state legislatures to call a national convention

options.label: C
options.text: A request from one-third of state legislatures to call a national convention

options.label: D
options.text: A request from one-third of state legislatures to call a national convention

multiple-choice.question: What is the Bill of Rights?

options.label: A
options.text: The first 10 amendments to the U.S. Constitution

options.label: B
options.text: The last 10 amendments to the U.S. Constitution

options.label: C
options.text: The first 5 amendments to the U.S. Constitution

options.label: D
options.text: The last 5 amendments to the U.S. Constitution

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for the passage of the Thirteenth Amendment?

options.label: A
options.text: To resolve some conflicts from the original Constitutional Convention

options.label: C
options.text: To create a unified country from thirteen different colonies

options.label: D
options.text: To make the Constitution easier to change

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why it is difficult to pass amendments to the U.S. Constitution today?

options.label: A
options.text: The country has grown larger and more diverse

options.label: B
options.text: The founders of the United States were trying to create a unified country from thirteen different colonies

options.label: C
options.text: The Constitution's creators wanted to make it easy to change

options.label: D
options.text: The country has become more unified

multiple-choice.question: What is the simplest solution to make the Constitution easier to amend?

options.label: A
options.text: Lowering the thresholds required for proposal and ratification

options.label: B
options.text: Making the Constitution harder to change

options.label: C
options.text: Making the Constitution easier to change

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the U.S. Supreme Court has expanded its interpretation of existing constitutional laws?

options.label: A
options.text: To keep up with the times

options.label: B
options.text: To make the Constitution easier to change

options.label: C
options.text: To make the Constitution harder to change

options.label: D
options.text: To create a unified country from thirteen different colonies

options.label: C

title: The Turing test: Can a computer pass for a human? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: Who is the British computer scientist who proposed the idea for measuring artificial intelligence that would famously come to be known as the Turing test?

options.label: B
options.text: To measure a computer's ability to simulate human conversation

options.label: C
options.text: To evaluate a computer's ability to learn from experience

options.text: A prize awarded to the first computer to pass the Turing test

options.label: B
options.text: Statistically analyzing huge databases of real conversations

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to understand and process complex linguistic structures

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to understand and process complex logical reasoning

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to understand and process complex emotional intelligence

options.label: B
options.text: It was a test of a computer's ability to simulate human conversation

options.label: C
options.text: It was a test of a computer's ability to learn from experience

options.label: B

title: Does grammar matter? - Andreea S. Calude

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between prescriptivism and descriptivism in linguistics?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescriptivism focuses on spoken language, while descriptivism focuses on written language.

options.label: B
options.text: Prescriptivism emphasizes the importance of rules, while descriptivism emphasizes the importance of variation.

options.label: C
options.text: Prescriptivism is concerned with the history of language, while descriptivism is concerned with its current use.

options.label: D
options.text: Prescriptivism is concerned with the structure of language, while descriptivism is concerned with its meaning.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main argument of the prescriptivists in the debate between prescriptivism and descriptivism?

options.label: A
options.text: That language should be constantly changing to reflect the needs of speakers and listeners.

options.label: B
options.text: That language should follow consistent rules to ensure clarity and precision.

options.label: C
options.text: That language is a fixed system that should not be altered.

options.label: D
options.text: That language is a matter of personal preference.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main argument of the descriptivists in the debate between prescriptivism and descriptivism?

options.label: A
options.text: To establish a set of rules for language use.

options.label: B
options.text: To describe how people actually use language, without dictating what is "correct".

options.label: C
options.text: To eliminate variation in language use.

options.label: D
options.text: To promote the use of a particular dialect.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between spoken and written language, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Spoken language is more formal than written language.

options.label: B
options.text: Spoken language is more flexible than written language.

options.label: C
options.text: Spoken language is more precise than written language.

options.label: D
options.text: Spoken language is less important than written language.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main argument of the linguists who have understood that speech is a separate phenomenon from writing?

options.label: A
options.text: That speech is a more complex system than writing.

options.label: B
options.text: That speech is a more flexible system than writing.

options.label: C
options.text: That speech is a more fixed system than writing.

options.label: D
options.text: That speech is less important than writing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the approach that tries to understand and map the differences between spoken and written language without dictating what is "correct"?
What is the main benefit of prescriptivism, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It promotes the use of a particular dialect.

options.label: B
options.text: It informs people about the most common established patterns at a given point in time.

options.label: C
options.text: It eliminates variation in language use.

options.label: D
options.text: It promotes the use of a particular language.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main benefit of descriptivism, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It promotes the use of a particular dialect.

options.label: B
options.text: It gives us insight into how our minds work and the instinctive ways in which we structure our view of the world.

options.label: C
options.text: It eliminates variation in language use.

options.label: D
options.text: It promotes the use of a particular language.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the idea that language is a set of linguistic habits that are constantly being negotiated and reinvented by the entire group of language users?
What is the main idea of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: That language is a fixed system that should not be altered.

options.label: B
options.text: That language is a matter of personal preference.

options.label: C
options.text: That language is a complex and dynamic system that is constantly being negotiated and reinvented by the entire group of language users.

options.label: D
options.text: That language is less important than other forms of communication.

multiple-choice.question: Why do people risk their lives to climb Mount Everest?

options.label: B
options.text: To experience the view and reach the highest point on Earth.

options.label: C

title: The power of the placebo effect - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the placebo effect?

options.label: A
options.text: A phenomenon where people experience relief from ailments due to the power of their imagination.

options.label: B
options.text: A medical treatment that is proven to work but has no actual effect.

options.label: C
options.text: An unexplained phenomenon wherein drugs, treatments, and therapies that aren't supposed to have an effect, and are often fake, miraculously make people feel better.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of surgery that is performed to relieve symptoms.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term "placebo" derived from?

options.label: A
options.text: The Latin word for "I shall please".

options.label: B
options.text: The Latin word for "I shall heal".

options.label: C
options.text: The Latin word for "I shall cure".

options.label: D
options.text: The Latin word for "I shall suffer".

multiple-choice.question: Why were placebos initially used in medicine?

options.label: A
options.text: To test the effectiveness of new treatments.

options.label: C
options.text: To administer when proper drugs weren't available.

options.label: D
options.text: To convince patients that they were receiving real treatment.

multiple-choice.question: What form did placebos take in the past?

options.label: A
options.text: Sugar pills, water-filled injections, and sham surgeries.

options.label: B
options.text: Real treatments, fake treatments, and unknown treatments.

options.label: C
options.text: Placebos were not used in the past.

options.label: D
options.text: Placebos were only used in the 1950s.

multiple-choice.question: How are placebos used in clinical trials today?

options.label: A
options.text: As a standard tool to test new treatments.

options.label: B
options.text: As a control to fine-tune the trial so that the effects of the new versus the old or alternative drug can be precisely compared.

options.label: C
options.text: As a way to placate patients.

options.label: D
options.text: As a way to convince patients that they are receiving real treatment.

multiple-choice.question: What is the placebo effect capable of causing?

options.label: A
options.text: Measurable change in blood pressure, heart rate, and the release of pain-reducing chemicals.

options.label: B
options.text: Measurable change in blood pressure, heart rate, and the release of stress hormones.

options.label: C
options.text: Measurable change in blood pressure, heart rate, and the release of pain-easing chemicals.

options.label: D
options.text: Measurable change in blood pressure, heart rate, and the release of stress-reducing chemicals.

multiple-choice.question: What are some examples of ailments that patients have experienced relief from due to the placebo effect?

options.label: A
options.text: Heart problems, asthma, and severe pain.

options.label: B
options.text: High blood pressure, diabetes, and cancer.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it not necessary to celebrate the placebo effect?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is not a real phenomenon.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it can lead to patients missing out on proven treatments.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it can lead to patients relying on fake treatments.

title: 5 tips to improve your critical thinking - Samantha Agoos

multiple-choice.question: What is critical thinking?

options.label: A
options.text: A way of approaching a question that allows us to carefully deconstruct a situation, reveal its hidden issues, and make the best decision.

options.label: B
options.text: A way of approaching a question that allows us to make an impulsive decision without considering the consequences.

options.label: C
options.text: A way of approaching a question that allows us to choose an answer because it feels right.

options.label: D
options.text: A way of approaching a question that allows us to ignore the information and make a decision based on emotions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first step in the five-step process of critical thinking?
Why is it important to have a clear view of what you're trying to accomplish when approaching a situation?

options.label: A
options.text: So you can make an impulsive decision without considering the consequences.

options.label: B
options.text: So you can ignore the information and make a decision based on emotions.

options.label: C
options.text: So you can sift through the information critically, find what you're looking for, and decide whether the new fad really suits your needs.

options.label: D
options.text: So you can choose an answer because it feels right.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the tools used in critical thinking to help eliminate everything but the most useful and reliable information?
What is the fourth step in the five-step process of critical thinking?
What is one of the concepts that should be considered when facing a decision?

options.label: C
options.text: Is my interpretation of the information logically sound?

multiple-choice.question: Why should you consider the long-term effects of a decision?

options.label: A
options.text: So you can make an impulsive decision without considering the consequences.

options.label: B
options.text: So you can ignore the information and make a decision based on emotions.

options.label: C
options.text: So you can imagine the potential unintended consequences and make a more informed decision.

options.label: D
options.text: So you can choose an answer because it feels right.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the benefits of exploring other points of view when making a decision?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows you to ignore the information and make a decision based on emotions.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows you to make an impulsive decision without considering the consequences.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows you to explore alternatives, evaluate your own choices, and ultimately help you make more informed decisions.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows you to choose an answer because it feels right.

multiple-choice.question: What is critical thinking?

options.label: A
options.text: A way of approaching a question that allows us to carefully deconstruct a situation, reveal its hidden issues, and make the best decision.

options.label: B
options.text: A way of approaching a question that allows us to make an impulsive decision without considering the consequences.

options.label: C
options.text: A way of approaching a question that allows us to choose an answer because it feels right.

options.label: D
options.text: A way of approaching a question that allows us to ignore the information and make a decision based on emotions.

multiple-choice.question: What is critical thinking a tool that can help make the world a more reasonable place?

title: Johann Sebastian Bach's Life (The 3-Minute Version)

multiple-choice.question: Where was Johann Sebastian Bach born?
What was Bach's family background?

options.label: A
options.text: He came from a family of farmers.

options.label: B
options.text: He came from a family of musicians.

options.label: C
options.text: He came from a family of politicians.

options.label: D
options.text: He came from a family of artists.

multiple-choice.question: What was the term "Bach" synonymous with during Johann Sebastian Bach's lifetime?
What was Bach's primary occupation as a young man?
What is the name of one of Bach's most famous works for keyboard?

options.label: B
options.text: The Toccata and Fugue in D-minor

multiple-choice.question: What was the reason for the popularity of the Toccata and Fugue in D-minor?
What is the name of Bach's collection of church music composed for the four main churches in Leipzig?
What is the name of Bach's final composition?

options.label: C
options.text: The Toccata and Fugue in D-minor

multiple-choice.question: When did Bach die?
What is the significance of the nearly 40 Bach Festivals in the United States?

options.label: A
options.text: They showcase Bach's music to a wider audience.

options.label: B
options.text: They provide a platform for professional musicians to perform Bach's music.

options.label: C
options.text: They demonstrate Bach's popularity among professional musicians.

title: This is Sparta: Fierce warriors of the ancient world - Craig Zimmer

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary purpose of the Spartan education system?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce well-rounded individuals with a variety of skills.

options.label: B
options.text: To produce individuals who were loyal to their family above all else.

options.label: C
options.text: To produce individuals who were loyal to Sparta above all else.

options.label: D
options.text: To produce individuals who were skilled in the arts.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the place where Spartan boys were sent to be trained as warriors?
What was the purpose of the diamastigosis, a religious ritual in which teenage boys were whipped?

options.label: B
options.text: To teach them how to read and write.

options.label: D
options.text: To punish them for their misbehavior.

multiple-choice.question: What was it common for boys to die during the diamastigosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, it was a rare occurrence.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, it was a common occurrence.

multiple-choice.question: What was the curriculum for Spartan girls?

options.label: B
options.text: The arts, music, dance, reading, and writing.

multiple-choice.question: What was the belief in Sparta regarding women who could bear children?

options.label: A
options.text: That they were weak and incapable.

options.label: B
options.text: That they were strong and capable.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of a Spartan man dying in battle?

options.label: A
options.text: It was seen as a failure.

options.label: B
options.text: It was seen as a completion of one's duty to Sparta.

options.label: C
options.text: It was seen as a waste of life.

options.label: D
options.text: It was seen as a cause for celebration.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of a Spartan woman dying in childbirth?

options.label: A
options.text: It was seen as a failure.

options.label: B
options.text: It was seen as a completion of one's duty to Sparta.

options.label: C
options.text: It was seen as a waste of life.

options.label: D
options.text: It was seen as a cause for celebration.

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of the Spartan education system for girls?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce well-rounded individuals with a variety of skills.

options.label: B
options.text: To produce individuals who were loyal to their family above all else.

options.label: C
options.text: To produce individuals who were loyal to Sparta above all else.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of a Spartan woman's tombstone?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a symbol of her wealth and status.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a symbol of her duty to Sparta was complete.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a symbol of her beauty and charm.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a symbol of her family's love for her.

title: Can wildlife adapt to climate change? - Erin Eastwood

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that humans are adapting to climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: By evolving to have a longer lifespan.

options.label: B
options.text: By using technological advancements to find solutions.

options.label: D
options.text: By relying on evolution to solve the problem.

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of evolutionary adaptation in cases where species are under strong selective conditions?

options.label: A
options.text: It usually occurs over a long time scale of millions of years.

options.label: C
options.text: It is limited to certain species.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not possible in rapidly changing climates.

multiple-choice.question: What is a nonheritable change to an individual's physical traits?

options.label: A
options.text: A change that is passed down from parents to offspring.

options.label: B
options.text: A change that is not passed down from parents to offspring.

options.label: C
options.text: A change that occurs over a long time scale.

options.label: D
options.text: A change that is limited to certain species.

multiple-choice.question: Why are brown tawny owls flourishing today?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are the dominant color variant.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are the recessive color variant.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have an advantage in exposed forests.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are the most common color variant.

multiple-choice.question: What is one example of a species that has undergone a climate-change-adaptive genetic change?
Why have two spot ladybug populations shifted to the non-melanic color combination?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are the dominant color variant.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are the recessive color variant.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are less likely to overheat.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are more likely to overheat.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that wild thyme plants in Europe are adapting to climate change?
How many species have evolutionary adaptations to rapid climate change?
What is one way that scientists are helping species adapt to climate change?

options.label: B
options.text: By identifying and setting aside critical climate refuges.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that humans can help preserve biodiversity?

options.label: B
options.text: By identifying and setting aside critical climate refuges.

title: Why are there so many insects? - Murry Gans

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of individual insects on Earth?
Compared to the human population, how many times more insects are there?
What is the approximate percentage of all animals on Earth that are insects?
What is the main reason for insect abundance?

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to adapt to extreme environments

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate percentage of insect species that undergo complete metamorphosis?
What is an example of an insect that can survive in extreme environments?
What is the main advantage of insect exoskeletons?

options.label: B
options.text: They protect insects against the outside world

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an insect that feeds on blood?
What is an example of an insect that builds a niche around feces?
What is the main reason why insects are able to occupy hundreds of different niches across ecosystems?

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to adapt to extreme environments

title: How ancient art influenced modern art - Felipe Galindo

multiple-choice.question: What does the term "modern art" refer to?

options.label: A
options.text: A style of art that is popular at the moment.

options.label: B
options.text: A style of art that originated over 150 years ago.

options.label: C
options.text: A style of art that emphasizes traditional representation.

options.label: D
options.text: A style of art that originated in ancient civilizations.

multiple-choice.question: Who was inspired by the African mask acquired by Henri Matisse to create his artwork?
What was the name of the painting that Picasso created after being inspired by African masks?
What movement in art did the artists who were inspired by African art contribute to?
Who was a British sculptor who based many of his semi-abstract bronze sculptures on a replica of a chacmool?
What was the name of the series of compositions created by Josef Albers that were inspired by pyramids and local art he encountered in Mexico?
What was the question raised about the artists who were inspired by African art?

options.label: A
options.text: Were they playing the role of explorers or conquistadors?

options.label: B
options.text: Were they profiting from cultures they considered primitive?

options.label: C
options.text: Were they appropriating ideas from cultures they considered primitive?

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the exhibition of Picasso's painting "Les Demoiselles d'Avignon"?

options.label: A
options.text: The public was thrilled and critics praised it.

options.label: B
options.text: The public was shocked and critics denounced it as immoral.

options.label: C
options.text: The public was indifferent and critics ignored it.

options.label: D
options.text: The public was confused and critics were unsure.

multiple-choice.question: Who was a German Expressionist who drew on the aesthetics of African sculptures in his work?
What was the continent that British sculptor Henry Moore drew inspiration from for his semi-abstract bronze sculptures?

title: Why do we love? A philosophical inquiry - Skye C. Cleary

multiple-choice.question: What is the idea that love makes us whole, according to the ancient Greek philosopher Plato?

options.label: A
options.text: That we love because of our base desires.

options.label: B
options.text: That we love to escape our loneliness and suffering.

options.label: C
options.text: That we love to find a soulmate who'll make us feel whole again.

options.label: D
options.text: That we love to quench our physical and psychological desires.

multiple-choice.question: Which philosopher maintained that love based in sexual desire was a voluptuous illusion?
According to Bertrand Russell, why do we love?

options.label: A
options.text: To find a soulmate who'll make us feel whole again.

options.label: B
options.text: To quench our physical and psychological desires.

options.label: C
options.text: To escape our loneliness and suffering.

multiple-choice.question: What is the eight-fold path, according to Siddhrtha Gautama?

options.label: A
options.text: A program for extinguishing the fires of desire.

options.label: B
options.text: A program for satisfying our base desires.

options.label: C
options.text: A program for finding a soulmate who'll make us feel whole again.

options.label: D
options.text: A program for quenching our physical and psychological desires.

multiple-choice.question: Who illustrated the Buddhist sentiment that romantic love is folly in one of China's greatest classical novels?
What is the moral of the story in "Dream of the Red Chamber"?

options.label: B
options.text: That love is the desire to integrate with another.

options.label: C
options.text: That love is the best thing in life.

options.label: D
options.text: That love is an escape from our loneliness and suffering.

multiple-choice.question: According to Simone de Beauvoir, what is the problem with traditional romantic love?

options.label: A
options.text: It can be so captivating that we are tempted to make it our only reason for being.

multiple-choice.question: What does Simone de Beauvoir advise to avoid the trap of traditional romantic love?
According to Simone de Beauvoir, what is the desire that infuses our lives with meaning?

options.label: A
options.text: The desire to find a soulmate who'll make us feel whole again.

options.label: B
options.text: The desire to quench our physical and psychological desires.

options.label: C
options.text: The desire to integrate with another.

options.label: D
options.text: The desire to escape our loneliness and suffering.

multiple-choice.question: What is the final message of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: That love is the best thing in life.

options.label: B
options.text: That love is the worst thing in life.

options.label: C
options.text: That love is a complex and multifaceted emotion.

options.label: D
options.text: That love is a simple and straightforward emotion.

title: What outer space does to your body

multiple-choice.question: What happens to your spine in space?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes compressed due to gravity.

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes elongated due to lack of gravity.

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same due to zero gravity.

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes shorter due to weightlessness.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the heart change shape in space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's having to pump harder to pull blood up from your feet.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's not having to pump as hard to pull blood up from your feet.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's having to pump harder to push blood up to your head.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's not having to pump at all.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to your bones in space?

options.label: A
options.text: They become stronger and more dense.

options.label: B
options.text: They change shape and lose calcium.

options.label: C
options.text: They remain the same due to zero gravity.

options.label: D
options.text: They become weaker and more brittle.

multiple-choice.question: Why do astronauts wear glasses in space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they need to see better in low light conditions.

options.label: B
options.text: Because their vision changes due to changes in intracranial pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they need to see better in high altitudes.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they need to see better in zero gravity.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that astronauts keep their bones from atrophying in space?
What is one effect of being in a zero G environment on the body?
What is one reason why astronauts experience back pain in space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the lack of gravity.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the compression of the spine.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the change in intracranial pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the change in bone density.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that the body can change in space?

options.label: A
options.text: The heart gets smaller and changes shape.

options.label: B
options.text: The bones change shape and lose calcium.

options.label: C
options.text: The spine elongates and the body grows taller.

multiple-choice.question: Why do astronauts need to wear glasses in space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because their vision changes due to the lack of gravity.

options.label: B
options.text: Because their vision changes due to the change in intracranial pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: Because their vision changes due to the change in bone density.

options.label: D
options.text: Because their vision changes due to the change in heart shape.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why astronauts experience changes in their bodies in space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the lack of gravity.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the change in intracranial pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the change in bone density.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the spirit of exploration.

title: History vs. Napoleon Bonaparte - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What event in 1789 led to Europe being thrown into chaos?

options.label: A
options.text: The rise of the French monarchy

options.label: B
options.text: The eruption of the French Revolution

options.label: C
options.text: The invasion of France by neighboring countries

options.label: D
options.text: The fall of the Roman Empire

multiple-choice.question: Who emerged as a powerful figure to take charge of France in the midst of chaos?
What was the main reason for Napolon's rise to power, according to the prosecution?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a tyrant who wanted to impose his own will on France

options.label: B
options.text: He was a strong leader who could govern wisely and justly

options.label: C
options.text: He was a military officer who supported the French Revolution

options.label: D
options.text: He was a member of the Jacobin party

multiple-choice.question: What were some of the key achievements of the French Revolution that Napolon maintained?

options.label: A
options.text: Freedom of speech and the press

options.label: B
options.text: Abolition of hereditary privilege and equality before the law

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason for Napolon's invasions of neighboring countries, according to the defense?

options.label: A
options.text: He wanted to spread his own personal power and influence

options.label: B
options.text: He wanted to defend France from being crushed by European monarchies

options.label: C
options.text: He wanted to enforce a European-wide blockade of Britain

options.label: D
options.text: He wanted to hold onto his gains and maintain control of the continent

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Napolon's wars and invasions, according to the prosecution?

options.label: A
options.text: The spread of democratic and liberal ideals across Europe

options.label: B
options.text: The rise of nationalism and the increase in army sizes

options.label: C
options.text: Millions dead all over the continent and the shattering of the international order

options.label: D
options.text: The strengthening of the French monarchy

multiple-choice.question: What was Napolon's ultimate goal, according to the defense?

options.label: A
options.text: To conquer Europe and impose his own will on the continent

options.label: B
options.text: To spread democratic and liberal ideals across Europe

options.label: C
options.text: To maintain control of the continent and hold onto his gains

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Napolon's defeat in the Russian winter snows, according to the defense?

options.label: A
options.text: The end of his empire and the beginning of a new era of peace

options.label: B
options.text: The rise of a new and more powerful empire

options.label: C
options.text: The continuation of his empire and the spread of his ideals

options.label: D
options.text: The decline of his power and influence

multiple-choice.question: What was Napolon's legacy, according to the defense?

options.label: A
options.text: A tyrant who imposed his own will on France and Europe

options.label: B
options.text: A ruler full of contradictions who defended a popular revolution by imposing absolute dictatorship

options.label: C
options.text: A military leader who expanded France's borders and spread his influence

options.label: D
options.text: A statesman who maintained the balance of power in Europe

multiple-choice.question: What would European history have been like if it weren't for Napolon, according to the defense?

options.label: A
options.text: It would have been unimaginably better

options.label: B
options.text: It would have been unimaginably worse

options.label: C
options.text: It would have been the same

options.label: D
options.text: It would have been different, but not significantly so

title: #TEDEdChat: Redefining Leadership | Drew Dudley | Leading with Lollipops |

multiple-choice.question: What is the title of the speaker's talk?

options.label: D
options.text: "Changing the World One Person at a Time"

multiple-choice.question: What is the story that the speaker shares with the audience to redefine leadership?

options.label: A
options.text: A story about a successful business deal

options.label: B
options.text: A story about a person who made a difference in the world

options.label: C
options.text: A story about a moment that had a profound impact on someone's life

options.label: D
options.text: A story about a person who failed to achieve their goals

multiple-choice.question: What is the "lollipop moment" that the speaker talks about?

options.label: A
options.text: A moment of great success or achievement

options.label: B
options.text: A moment of failure or disappointment

options.label: C
options.text: A moment that has a profound impact on someone's life

options.label: D
options.text: A moment of great joy or happiness

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's call to action?

options.label: A
options.text: To change the world through big actions

options.label: B
options.text: To redefine leadership as being about creating lollipop moments

options.label: C
options.text: To focus on changing the world through small actions

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the impact that we can have on each other's lives

multiple-choice.question: Who said, "Our greatest fear is not that we are inadequate. It is that we are powerful beyond measure. It is our light, and not our darkness, that frightens us"?
What is the main idea that the speaker wants to convey to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: That leadership is about changing the world

options.label: B
options.text: That leadership is about creating lollipop moments

options.label: C
options.text: That leadership is about achieving great success

options.label: D
options.text: That leadership is about being powerful

multiple-choice.question: How many people does the speaker estimate are affected by our actions?
What is the speaker's goal in redefining leadership?
What is the speaker's message to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: To be more confident in their abilities

options.label: B
options.text: To be more fearful of their power

options.label: C
options.text: To be more grateful for the impact they can have on others

options.label: D
options.text: To be more focused on changing the world

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final thought?

options.label: A
options.text: That leadership is a complex issue

options.label: B
options.text: That leadership is a simple issue

options.label: C
options.text: That leadership is about creating lollipop moments

options.label: D
options.text: That leadership is about changing the world

title: The beneficial bacteria that make delicious food - Erez Garty

multiple-choice.question: What type of organisms are responsible for making bread, beer, and wine?
What is the main difference between the aerobic and anaerobic pathways used by yeast?

options.label: A
options.text: The aerobic pathway produces more ethanol, while the anaerobic pathway produces more CO2.

options.label: B
options.text: The aerobic pathway produces more CO2, while the anaerobic pathway produces more ethanol.

options.label: C
options.text: The aerobic pathway produces water, while the anaerobic pathway produces carbon dioxide.

options.label: D
options.text: The aerobic pathway produces carbon dioxide, while the anaerobic pathway produces water.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the carbon dioxide produced during the fermentation process in bread-making?

options.label: A
options.text: It is absorbed by the yeast.

options.label: B
options.text: It is released into the atmosphere.

options.label: C
options.text: It gets trapped by gluten and creates a sponge-like structure in the bread.

options.label: D
options.text: It is used to make the bread more dense.

multiple-choice.question: What type of microorganism is responsible for turning a tart compound in grape juice into softer tasting ones in red wines and chardonnays?
What happens to the ethanol in wine if there is oxygen around and acetic acid bacteria are present?

options.label: A
options.text: It is converted into acetic acid.

options.label: B
options.text: It is absorbed by the yeast.

options.label: C
options.text: It is released into the atmosphere.

options.label: D
options.text: It is used to make the wine more sweet.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of adding rennet to milk in cheese-making?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the milk more acidic.

options.label: C
options.text: To help the proteins aggregate and curdle.

options.label: D
options.text: To make the milk more sweet.

multiple-choice.question: What type of microorganism is responsible for giving Swiss cheese its characteristic holes?

options.label: D
options.text: A species of bacteria that emits carbon dioxide.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of acetic acid bacteria in wine?

options.label: A
options.text: They make the wine more sweet.

options.label: B
options.text: They make the wine more acidic.

options.label: C
options.text: They convert the ethanol in wine into acetic acid.

options.label: D
options.text: They make the wine more bitter.

multiple-choice.question: What type of microorganism is responsible for making yogurt, soy sauce, sour cream, sauerkraut, kefir, kimchi, kombucha, cheddar, challah, pita, and naan?
What is the purpose of using a vent in carbonated alcoholic beverages like champagne and beer?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the drink more sweet.

options.label: B
options.text: to make the drink more acidic.

options.label: D
options.text: to make the drink more bitter.
